channel.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
channel.description:
Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
I don't know why, but I have thought of at least one person doing this. A sort of 'white-hat' kind of hacker that has a script running, checking IPs, using common exploits to get into each one, and if it does get into it, then it runs a series of scripts to clean up shit and close open holes. Then leaves discreetly and moves on to the next person.
Just a little philosophy to discuss. :)
It would be pretty sick if someone did this and [i]then[/i] posted the script on the net for people to download. Anyone who has a clean computer could just download it and keep checking for exploitable computers and make the Internet safe from those jack ass hackers.

item.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
item.dc:creator: @Martin Martin
item.description:
@Martin wrote:

Well i’ve heard of people who work for the bank that try to exploit their site so that the can patch it up. Other than that I doubt any hacker is this nice.

Read full topic

item.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
item.dc:creator: @TeraByte TeraByte
item.description:
@TeraByte wrote:

Of course, black hat hackers could then post their own “Help Clean People’s PC’s!” programs which are actually harmful, and then you would have a mixture of remote-cleaning programs, some good, some bad, and it would all somewhat balance out and you would have the same situation as you had before.

Read full topic

item.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Well actually, I’ve been doing this a lot without realizing it! Let me just quote my other post:

The Un-Named:

I personally think anyone that would help some fat-ass rich kid that doesn’t know how to use a search engine is sick in the head, however I would think white hat hackers would “hack” their legit friends pc’s or servers or whatever and patch them up.

My friend recently bought wireless and I noticed the day it went up(Only connection I can get perfect signal on in my front room) and it was unprotected so I setup a network key and posted it though his door. Obviously not uber hacking but from what I can tell, you can do some major damage if you have access(witch I did(192.168.1.1, login: “admin” “password”)) to the router setup.

Read full topic
item.source: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?

item.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
item.dc:creator: @instrus instrus
item.description:
@instrus wrote:

When I said remote location, I meant by the personal exploiting it. [quote=“k00dr, post:6, topic:107959”]On topic: Yes, I believe some white hats who discover new critical bugs may out of interest exploit a bug and fix it.[/quote]s/fix/tell software vendor or publicly disclose/

In the context of this thread, nobody is going to go round remotely patching vulnerable machines.

Read full topic
item.source: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?

item.title: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

instrus:

Remote exploits tend to be not fixable from a remote location, they require the software vendor to issue a patch - otherwise there wouldn’t be any problems with exploited software, vendors would be able to real-time patch the entire world with no user intervention.

That’s bullshit.
Of course they are fixable “from a remote location”, it’s just patching or replacing files over remote shell.
And no, of course vendors wouldn’t EXPLOIT their own software (in order to patch it).

On topic: Yes, I believe some white hats who discover new critical bugs may out of interest exploit a bug and fix it.

Read full topic
item.source: Ever wonder if there are hackers that cleans peoples' computers?
